This is a development that has taken him a long time to realize, and not until he was able to join his lending group and was given the idea. He now sees a change in his life, family, and business since every one is happy now. He sells his eggs in Mityana town and Kampala where the market is big. Henry needs a loan to help with buying more feed for his chicks and hiring manpower on his farm.

loans.use: Chicken feed and payroll

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.es: La Sra. Benedicta C., se dedica actualmente a la venta de estuco, también tiene una pequeña tienda, pero se dedica más a la venta de estuco, ella trabajo el año 2007 con dos secuencias de crédito, luego descanso un tiempo y retornó solicitando dos mil bolivianos para compra de estuco y para compra de semilla, ya que al margen de sus actividades ella posee tierras de cultivo en Palca, poblado cercano a la ciudad de La Paz, donde siembran productos alimenticios como verduras. Ella tiene tres hijos en edad escolar, el esposo es albañil, tiene domicilio en alquiler, aunque tiene terrenos de su propiedad pero sin edificaciones, ella es una persona responsable y de buena actitud.
texts.en:
Sra. Benedicta C. operates a business selling supplies of stucco. She also owns a small store, but she spends more time working at stucco sales. She worked in 2007 with two consecutive loans, took some time off, then came back with a request for two thousand bolivianos to buy both stucco and seeds. In addition to her other businesses, she owns farmland in Palca, a town near the city of La Paz, where she grows food crops such as vegetables. Benedicta has three school-aged children and her husband is a construction worker. She has a rented house and land, without buildings, that she owns. She is a responsible person with a great attitude.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy stucco for construction supplies business.

loans.name: Nwanneka

texts.en: B. is 32 years old. She sells clothes and drinks and she is also a fashion designer with two apprentices. B. learned her business in two years and she has been in the business for the past fifteen years. She hopes for the loan of N70,000 to purchase more clothes and drinks to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and drinks to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.fr: Cette femme âgée de 37 ans  est venue s’installer depuis plusieurs années déjà à lomé. Actuellement elle est divorcée de son mari et a à sa charge ses deux enfants. L’activité génératrice de revenu qu’elle exerce et qui lui permet de  subvenir de façon convenable aux besoins de ses enfants est la vente de charbons de bois. Elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays. Voulant agrandir son stock pour mieux vendre, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 20 sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en:
This woman, age 37, came to Lomé to establish herself several years ago already. Currently, she is divorced, and she has two children in her care. Selling charcoal is the revenue-generating business that she operates and that allows her to support her children appropriately. She stocks up from the country’s interior. Wanting to expand her stock in order to sell more, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 20 sacks of charcoal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Sifa

texts.en:
Greetings from Kigali-Rwanda

Sifa is 29 years old, she is married ,she has three children with the ages of 12,10,4 and one dependent.

Sifa owns a small shop selling clothes in Nyabugogo market at Kigali since 1998.She works every day from 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM and the monthly profit is 150,000 RWF.

Sifa is requesting her first  loan of 500,000 RWF from  Vision Finance Company s.a   .With this new loan, Sifa hopes to expand her business through purchasing more clothes for sales and as she will be getting more profits, she hopes also to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: clothes

loans.name: María

texts.es:
La señora María de 45 años de edad es casada hace mas de 20 años con el Señor Lázaro y tienen dos hijas de las cuales una ya esta casada y no vive con ella y la que es menor de edad esta terminando su estudios primarios en un colegio público.

Cabe destacar que posee un local comercial en la Zona Baja en el ramo de ventas de Ropas y Calzados para Damas, Caballeros y Niños hace mas de 8 años de funcionamiento y es atendida por ella misma y su cónyuge trabaja como fletero con su propio vehículo y realiza flete en el mercado fronterizo ya hace varios años y así también le ayuda en los compromisos del hogar. 

El destino del crédito es para la compra de ropas de Buenos Aires (Argentina), ella las compra de ahí por que el costo es mucho menor y así le deja mayor margen de ganancia.
texts.en:
Sra. María is 45 years old and has been married for over 20 years to Sr. Lázaro. They have two daughters. One is already married and no longer lives at home. The younger daughter is finishing her studies at a public college.

She owns a shop in La Zona Baja (the Lower Area) where she sells clothes and shoes for women, men and children. Her business has been operation for 8 years and she manages it by herself. Her husband works as chartered freight driver with his own vehicle. He has worked in the freight business for several years and helps with the household expenses.

Sra. María will use her loan to purchase clothes from Buenos Aires (Argentina), where she can obtain merchandise at a much lower cost. This gives her a larger profit margin.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase women's winter clothing

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy L. is a married woman and a Tanzanian small-business entrepreneur. She runs a shop selling traditional clothes at Kigamboni, Dar es Salaam. She sells khanga (printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides), vitenge (a traditional Tanzanian cloth with wax print) and batik (cotton cloth dyed after brushing on hot liquid wax to protect desired areas). These types of clothes are highly used by Tanzanian women and the East African women as a whole.

Teddy purchases the business goods wholesale from the Mnazi Mmoja traditional city market center in and sells to her customers. She has been in the business for four years and the business income enables her to meet her daily needs and those of the family.

Teddy is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,000,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Flora

texts.ru: Ли Флора проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст 61 год. Замужем, имеет 1 ребенка. Ли более 15 лет занимается продажей корейских салатов на рынке, где имеет торговую точку. По специальности Ли "экономист". Кредит просит для закупа сырья, чтобы загатовить салаты. С полученной прибыли хочет отремонтировать свой дом.
texts.en:
L. Flora lives in the Shahrituz region. She is 61 years old. She is married and has one child. L. has been selling Korean salads on the market where she has a vendor space for more than fifteen years. L.'s profession is an economist. She is asking for a loan to buy products to prepare the salads. She will use the profit she makes to repair her home.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products for salads

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
Robinah is a 45 year single mother of 2 children, who are between 8 and 20 years old. All of her children go to school. She owns a four room house, in which she resides with seven people. Robinah takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and running water at home.

Robinah works in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of Kampala. She uses public transport to get to and from this area. Robinah doesn’t pay rent but does pay daily market dues. She is faced with the rainy season as well.

Robina sells to all categories of people both wholesale and retail. She works seven days a week. Her monthly expenses include medication and feeding the family. 

She has been in this kind of business for ten years and with MCDT for three years; this is her sixth loan. She aspires to build up her business and eventually sell only wholesale.

loans.use: purchasing more used clothing

loans.name: Azucena Gioconda

texts.es:
En el departamento de León, la señora Azucena M. se ha destacado por ser una persona muy trabajadora que ha venido mejorando sus condiciones de vida puesto que inició su negocio de salón de belleza y aunque su local no presenta las condiciones necesaria, ella ha venido desarrollándose poco a poco.

Solicita el crédito para la compra de los materiales de trabajo como lo son peines, gelatinas, cremas, tintes, pinturas de uña, entre otros. Ella espera confiadamente en que su crédito le será otorgado y de esta manera mejorará su condición.
texts.en:
In the department of León, Azucena M. stands out for being a very hard-working person. She has come to improve her living conditions through starting a beauty salon business. Although the premises don't present the necessary conditions, she has come to develop the business bit by bit.

Azucena is requesting a loan to buy work materials such as combs, gels, creams, dyes and nail paints, among others. She hopes confidently that the loan will be granted and in this way she will improve her situation.

Translated from Spanish by Stephen Bayley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of work materials for her beauty salon

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Eva M. from Mbozi. She is married with four children between the ages of 7 and 20. Eva has been running a crops business since 2003, purchasing and selling crops. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, six days per week. Eva currently earns about 90 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase crops in bulk for her business. In the future, she plans to improve the quality and range of her products. Eva thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita G. is from the village of Bayabo East. She is 31 years-old and married with one baby. Juanita owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and other goods. Juanita just started this business.

In 2009, Juanita joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juanita is requesting a first loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Lona

texts.en:
Lona S. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Lona is 25 years old and is married with a husband who is a soldier. She has one child and the child goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en: Altantsetseg is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her elder daughter, Zolzaya, who is 8 years old, currently attends a local secondary school while her younger child, Zolbayar, who is 6 years old, is in kindergarten. Altantsetseg operates a dairy trading business with the help of her husband in her town. She started her business in 2007 with working capital of 100,000 tugrugs (~70 USD) and has built a stable operation over the years. Today, she is well established in the local business community and attributes her success to her strong customer base, communication skills and good accounting practices. Altantsetseg also has many reliable suppliers, many of which sell exclusively to her. Today, her working capital exceeds 400,000 tugrugs (~280 USD). For the future, Altantsetseg hopes to own her own workspace, which will allow her to serve more customers. She is requesting a 400,000 tugrug loan to purchase more dairy products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products

loans.name: Junior Ismael

texts.es:
El señor Junior Ismael E. vive en el municipio de Telica en el departamento de León y se ha dedicado al servicio de transporte de taxi llevando pasajeros de una distancia a otra y cobrando de acuerdo a la distancia recorrida.
Junior es casado y con tres hijos a los que mantiene por lo que con gran ahínco se dedica a trabajar para llevar el sustento a su hogar. El crédito que está solicitando lo invertirá en la inversión para el taxi y también en el pago de la concesión de placa para así circular sin ningún problema en el municipio. Espera que su crédito le sea otorgado a lo inmediato y así mejorará sus condiciones de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Junior Ismael E. lives in the Telica municipality in the Leon department. He drives a taxi taking passengers and charging them according to the distance. Junior is married and has 3 children. In order to provide for them he is devoted to his work. He is requiring a loan to invest in his taxi and also to pay for the registration fees to drive without restrictions by the municipality. He hopes to obtain this loan soon to improve his family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Wright, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in his taxi

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy merchandise for her food market

loans.name: Chirrojop Group

texts.es: Son un grupo de personas que se dedican a la confeccion de ropas de vestir tales como pantalones, chumpas, playeras, y entre otras prendas, desde hace más de 2 años cuentan con experiencia lo que hace que en el tiempo necesitan más capital de trabajo, por esa razón han acudido a las oficinas de la Asociación ASDIR, a presentar una solicitud de prestamo para el aumento de capital de trabajo, y de esa manera podrán obtener mejores ganancias,asi también mejorar sus condiciones de vida para su familia, esta actividad ayuda a la comunidad con los costos bajos de sus productos muchas personas se benefician y logran desarrollar una actividad
texts.en:
They are a group of people who are dedicated to making clothing such as trousers, jackets, and shirts, among other items. They have over two years' experience with what they do, which they now need more working capital for. For this reason, they have approached the offices of the ASDIR Association to present a loan request for an expansion of working capital. In this manner, they will be able to obtain better earnings and also improve the living conditions for their families. This activity helps the community with low prices for their products. Many people benefit and are able to develop an activity.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital.

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Norma es socia del Banco Comunal Perla.
Norma es conviviente, tiene 32 años y 3 hijos, Norma tiene un puesto en el mercado 12 de abril en donde vende abarrotes en general y especerías, actividad que realiza todos los días. Norma necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ají, comino, canela, arroz y azúcar.
Norma sueña con salir adelante y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Norma is a member of the Perla (Pearl) communal bank. She lives with her life partner, is 32 years old, and has three children. Norma has a stand in the 12 de Abril market where she sells groceries and spices every day. Norma needs 1050 soles to buy chili, cumin, cinnamon, rice and sugar. Norma dreams with getting ahead in life and providing a good education for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chili, cumin, cinnamon, rice and sugar.

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
Francisco es un padre de familia de 60 años de edad que vive junto a su esposa en el sector La Pilca del distrito de Olmos, en la provincia de Lambayeque, ubicado a hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales menores desde hace más de tres años. El cría ganado ovino y caprino en un ambiente instalado en la parte posterior de su vivienda para venderlos a los negociantes que frecuentan la zona. Este negocio es de suma importancia para la economía de su familia, ya que le provee de ingresos permanentes con los cuales puede mantenerse. Adicionalmente se dedica a la agricultura, pero esta actividad no le provee de ingresos permanentes.

Francisco da lo mejor de si para sacar su negocio adelante, el desea aumentar las ganancias de su negocio brindandole buena alimentación a sus animales para que la calidad de estos sea mejor, por ello se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de alimento balanceado.

Francisco es un padre bastante responsable y que siempre ha velado por el bienestar de los suyos. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado ser un cliente puntual y responsable al momento de asumir sus pagos.
texts.en:
Francisco is a 60 year old father who lives with his wife in the sector of La Pilca in Olmos District, Lambayeque Province, which is located 1½ hours away from the city of Chiclayo.

He has been raising and selling small animals for more than three years. The sheep and goats that he raises are kept in an area behind his house and are sold to dealers who frequent the area. This business is of great importance to his family’s economic situation, since it provides a steady income in order for them to survive. Francisco is also engaged in farming, but this activity does not provide steady income.

Francisco gives his best in order to succeed in his business. He wants to increase his business earnings by providing better nutrition to his animals so that their quality will improve. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of 500 PEN from Edpyme Alternativa so that he can invest in the purchase of nutritional feed.

Francisco is a responsible father who always provides for the welfare of his family. He has worked previously with our Institution and has demonstrated that he is a punctual and responsible client when making his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase feed for his sheep & goats

loans.name: Sarat

texts.en: Sarat is a business man and he loves his business so much. He sells phone accessories at retail prices to his customers to make a living in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. He is married and has 2 children. He is 37 years old and his wife also works to support their home. He has been in this business for 4 years and he hopes to grow his business to become bigger and stronger. Sarat is requesting for a loan amount of NGN50,000 to purchase more phone accessories to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories to sell.

loans.name: Poni

texts.en: Poni G. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and rice and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans to sell. Poni is 48 years old and is widowed. She has two children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house and put it up for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of beans to sell

loans.name: Rosita Nabaluna's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Rosita N., 52 years of age and married, is a resident of Dimalco, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. Rosita is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosita N.’s Group.
	
Rosita is married to Bonifacio N., a fisherman, and they are blessed with 6 children, 4 of whom are adults and the other 2 are of school age. To help her husband in supporting their family, she decided to engage in a little business operating a sari-sari (variety) store. For 10 years now she has been able to manage this little business and she is now earning an average net income of not less than PHP 4,000 a month, which is so helpful to their family's income.

She joined the cooperative in 2009.  As an active member and at the same time the center chief of the Jakarta center of the PDP-LP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) of Paglaum MPC, a micro-finance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she is requesting an amount of PHP 6,500 as her second loan for the purpose of adding to her capital for her existing business activity, which is a sari-sari (variety) store business.

The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions of her family, to meet their basic needs and for savings for future use. She is hoping that someday her business will become more progressive.


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari (variety) store

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Danaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Sompiya, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de bétail, de savon, d’arachide et d’articles divers.
Ces femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du bétail, du savon kabakourouni et de l’arachide et beaucoup d’articles divers.
AWA C. du groupe Danaya compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, du bétail  pour le revendre.
Elle s’approvisionne en bétail  le plus généralement sur place et effectue sa vente sur place, dans le village de Sompiya, au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Danaya group are all married, are an average of 41 years old, have three children and live in traditional extended families in Sompiya, in the Dioïla prefecture in the region of Koulikoro (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other through family ties and are in the business of selling livestock, soap, peanuts and various other items. The women of the Danaya group are on their first joint loan which will be used to buy livestock, Kabakourouni soap (a locally made soap), peanuts and numerous other items. Awa C. of the Danaya group plans to use her loan to buy livestock and to resell it. She usually gets her supplies of livestock locally and makes her sales in the village of Sompiya, for cash, to a clientele of men and women. She plans to make an average monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA which will be used to meet daily family expenses and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy livestock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase materials to make shoes

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
41-year-old Evelyn R. is a married woman with ten children. She is from the town of Sto. Niño. She still has children who go to school and she works hard to sustain their education. She has been engaged in farming for more than twenty four years now. She and her husband till their land for rice crops. She sells their harvest at the local market. She also raises pigs for breeding.

In February 2007, Evelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Evelyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Komdin Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Komdin” group. They are businesswomen with small-scale businesses in the small town of Waterloo, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with SMT to start a branch. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit, and consequently improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Neneh F.. Neneh, who was born in Kambia, northern Sierra Leone, is age thirty-two and is married with three children. Now, she lives in Waterloo with her husband and children. Her husband is a businessman and two of her children are attending primary school.

Neneh sells firewood, charcoal and foodstuffs and has been a businesswoman for five years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy more firewood and charcoal wholesale to add to her current stock. 

Attached to the group photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and charcoal wholesale to add to her current stock

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Group

texts.es:
La señora Eusebia Olmeddo es una señora que se dedica a la venta de pezcado, posee un pequeño puesto en donde concurren varías personas cada día, es así que  ella decidio formar un pequeño comité de mujeres emprendedoras con sus vecinas de la cuadra, invito a las más responsables, y actualmente se encuentran con muchas ganas de seguir adelante en sus trabajos diarios, son 17 señoras independientes en su trabajos, que recibiran un capacitaciones de acuerdo al ciclo donde se encuentran. 
Las mismas desean contar siempre con el apoyo crediticio de la Fundación Paraguaya, que les ayuda muchisimo para el emprendimiento de cada una de  ellas en las actividades que realizan.
Ella solicita el préstamo para la compra de pezcado.
texts.en:
Eusebia Olmeddo sells fish. She has a small stand, which various people frequent everyday. She decided to form a small group of enterprising women with her neighbors on the block. She invited the most responsible people. They now have a great desire to get ahead in their daily work. There are 17 women in the group, and they work independently. They will get trainings according to the cycle they are in. They want to always count on the loan support from the Fundación Paraguaya. It helps them so much in each one of their endeavors. She is requesting the loan to buy fish.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fish

loans.name: Manito Poderosa Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario Manito Poderosa lo conforman Leyla Francisca
texts.en: The “Manito Poderosa” (Powerful Hand) Communal Bank is comprised of Leyla Francisca

loans.use: Buy supplies

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a widowed woman with three children, who all attend school.  She rents a house with no electricity or water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

She has been running a retail shop for five years and previously was a shopkeeper for a businessman. The local community makes up the major number of customers for her business. Her greatest challenge is seasonality as she experiences low sales of most of the foodstuffs when the community harvests heavily from their farms.

With the 40,000 KES loan, Lucy wants to buy bales of wheat flour, cooking oil and major cereals such as beans and peas. She hopes someday to expand her shop to a bigger one.

loans.use: Buy bales of wheat flour, cooking oil and cereals

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona A. is from Agay-ayan, Gingoog City. She is 40 years old, married, and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Chona owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling fruit like durian (a large, round, odorous fruit) and wild berries in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Chona joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fruit to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fruit to sell

loans.name: Walter

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal  “SEÑOR PAN DE AZUCAR ”;  El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac, provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

El socio es el Sr. Walter;   el tiene 37 años de edad, es casado; y tiene 2 hijos,  El socio se dedica a la venta de zapatos en el distrito de Calca; él  trabaja en el mercado modelo en Calca y tiene su stand en la cual exhibe sus zapatos para la venta. El socio requiere el préstamo para poder implementar su negocio y mejorar su mercadería, el debe comprar un poco de mercadería y organizar su negocio. El socio solicita el préstamo para comprar mercadería e implementar su negocio.

El socio agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Walter is a member of the “SEÑOR PAN DE AZUCAR” (Lord Bread of Sugar) communal bank, located in the Huanchac district, in the province and department of Cusco.

He is 37 years old, married, and has 2 children.  He sells shoes from a stand, where he shows his shoes for sale, in the main market in the Calca district.

He is asking for this loan in so that he can invest into his business and improve his merchandise.  He needs to buy a bit of merchandise and organize his business.

He is grateful and values the loan facilitated in this manner and promises to make his payments on schedule.

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Abavandimwe Group

texts.en:
Jeanne is 47 years old and her husband is a driver. They have eight children between the ages of two and 26. Two of them have completed their studies. Five more go to school, while the youngest is not yet of school age. Jeanne is a group leader of Abavandimwe Group. Abavandimwe is a Kinyarwanda word that means “The Relatives” in English.  
She sells beans and with this loan she will buy more beans to sell. With the profit, she will pay school fees for her children. She dreams of having a big market where she can supply a larger quantity than what she has been selling. In the photo, Jeanne is the one with glasses.

loans.use: To buy more beans to sell.

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es: La Sra. Ana María  trabaja con la institución desde hace bastante tiempo para ser mas exactos  desde el año 2005, es una cliente muy responsable y de buena actitud ya que nunca tubo problemas en el pago de sus cuotas, la señora tiene una librería- bazar  que atiende todos los días, en la tarde le acompaña su hija que estudia en un colegio de la zona, en la misma librería la señora realiza trabajos de pintado en tela con lo cual se ayuda y como un pasatiempo, su esposo trabaja como fisioterapeuta en un l instituto,  El crédito que solicita es para la compra de material escolar para la librería, quiere surtir su librería, esta muy agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en: Mrs. Ana Maria has dealt with the lending institution for some time, since 2005 to be exact.  She is a very responsible client with a good attitude and has never had a problem making her payments.  She runs a bookstore in which she works every day.  In the evenings she accompanies her daughter who goes to school in the area.  She also creates paintings in her store, both for income and as a hobby.  Her husband works as a physical therapist in an institute.  The loan she is requesting is for buying school supplies for her bookstore.  She is very grateful to the institution for the help she has been given.

loans.use: Purchase of school supplies

loans.name: Marie Claudine

texts.en:
Marie Claudine is 26 years old and married to a vet. She has two young children who are nine months and four years old. Her oldest child attends school. Marie Claudine sells seeds and fertilizers. She has been in this business for about four years. 

She would like to get a loan to purchase additional seeds and fertilizers to sell.  She is pleased with her business as it allows her to provide for the needs of her family. 

The profit from this business will be used to buy a cow to provide milk for her children. In the future, she hopes to get a larger loan amount of 800,000 Rwandan francs.

loans.use: To buy  more seeds and fertilizers to sell

loans.name: Las Camelias Group

texts.es:
Julia es socia del Bancomunal Las Camelias, tiene 36 años, es casada y tiene 2 hijos.
Julia se dedica a la venta D. ropa para: damas, caballeros, niños y también es artesana, elabora  bolsos chullos, flores y hace bordados.
El crédito que solicita lo invertirá para surtir su mercadería (ropas: niños, caballeros, damas), ahora que ya se aproxima la campaña naviD.ña. AtienD. sólo pedidos el cual le pagan a diario, en partes o al instante.
Le gusta Finca porque le hablan sobre como hacer negocios y aprendió a ahorrar.
Su sueño es que crezca su negocio y poder tener una tienda, tambien esta ahorrando para la Educación D. sus hijos y comprarse un casa propia.
texts.en:
Julia is a member of the Las Camelias Communal Bank. She is a 36-year-old married mother of 2 children. She sells apparel for men, women, and children. She also makes handicrafts like bags, knit Peruvian hats with earflaps, and embroidery.

She will invest this loan in obtaining merchandise (apparel for men, women, and children) now that the Christmas season is approaching. She only sells by order and is paid daily, in installments, or at the moment of purchase.

She likes Finca because they tell her how to do business, and she has learned how to save money. Her dream is for her business to grow and for her to own a store. She is also saving money for her children's education and to buy a house.

loans.use: Apparel for men, women, and children

loans.name: Eloy Guillermo

texts.es:
Eloy de 55 años,  es un hombre trabajador que por algunos problemas de la empresa donde trabajaba hace varios años atrás tuvo que salir y se quedo sin trabajo. Pero por ese inconveniente no se detuvo a esperar una oportunidad de trabajo sino que opto por invertir sus  ahorros y comprar víveres para tener una tienda. 
  
Ubico la tienda en la parte delantera de su casa y la surtió con distintos productos de primera necesidad hasta que un día tuvo un accidente se cayó de un segundo piso y se fracturo algunos huesos por eso su esposa tuvo que vender los productos de la tienda para tener dinero y pagar el tratamiento. Por la dedicación que  tenia y las fuerzas para mantener a su familia hace un año se recupero y empezó nuevamente la tienda para generar ingresos y darles un buen futuro a sus hijos. En la actualidad vive en un cantón llamado Playas uno de los lugares turísticos del Ecuador con una diversa dimensión de mariscos y trabaja desde las 07h00am hasta las 19h00pm todos los días. 

Para seguir trabajando y surtir más su tienda él quiere comprar con el préstamo arroz, aceite, lácteos. En el futuro quiere surtir su tienda con mercadería y construir mejor su casa.
texts.en:
Eloy, age 55, is a hardworking man. Due to some problems at the business where he used to work, he had to leave and found himself without employment. This setback didn’t stop him from hoping for an opportunity for work, and he opted to invest his savings and purchase supplies in order to have a shop.

He located the shop in the front part of his house and stocked it with basic necessities. One day, he had an accident. He fell from a second story window and fractured some bones. That’s why his wife had to sell the shop’s products in order to have money and pay for his treatment. Because of her dedication and strength in maintaining the family he recovered after one year and began the shop anew in order to generate income and give a good future to their children.

Currently he lives in a canton called Playas, one of Ecuador’s tourist areas, noted for its diverse seafood. He works from 7:00 a.m. until 7:00 p.m. every day. In order to continue working and to stock his store better he wants to use the loan to purchase rice, oil, and dairy products. In the future he wants to stock his store’s inventory and improve his house.

loans.use: To purchase rice, oil, and dairy products

loans.name: The Arab Women´s Bank Group

texts.en:
The Arab Women's Bank is made up of eight members who live in Pococí, Limón, located near the Carribbean coast of Costa Rica. These hardworking entrepreneurs are involved in various revenue-generating activities, including clothing sales, manicure/pedicure services, sewing/alteration services, and catalog sales. In general, this loan will be used by each individual member to make investments in her specific business activity. Vendors of catalog items will invest in merchandise such as clothing, DVDs, pots, pans, perfumes, and jewelry. Seamstresses will purchase fabric, thread, and needles in order to produce clothing for sale. Some members will use this loan to invest in nail polish and other tools necessary for providing manicure and pedicure services. The members of this group offer their products and services to clients in their immediate community as well as to people in neighboring communities. 

The loan consultant who has been working with these women describes them as a tight-knit group with much experience in their individual businesses and the mutual goal of attaining a higher standard of living within their communities and families. The name of this group comes from the Bible. To the members of the group, Arab refers to growth and expansion, both of which are central values for this group. 

Emma Q. Cevrato is a 35-year-old mother of four who lives with her family in Pococí. She is also the elected president of this group. Emma is involved in two types of business: sewing/alteration services and the sale of brand-name clothing. She says the secret to organizing her day in a productive manner is keeping to a schedule. She designates blocks of time to take care of domestic tasks and blocks of time to her business. When she is very busy, her children assist her by tending to the sales part of the business while their mother sews in her workshop. Emma's goals are to expand her business and grow her list of clients. Her dream is to own a business separate from her home. With respect to her family, the immediate goal is to establish economic stability. The main obstacle to her progress is a lack of working capital funds in order to invest in sewing materials such as thread, needles, and fabric, as well as clothing merchandise. 

The members of the Arab Women´s Bank are neighbours and friends who have lived in the same rural community for the majority of their lives. They identify the main advantage of the group lending model as the ability of each member, without collateral or credit, to act as a guarantor for other members, which enables each member to receive a loan. The main disadvantage they identified was the possibility that if somebody defaults in the group, or has trouble repaying their loan, this implies a responsibility to act in support by the other members of the group.

loans.use: For the purchase of clothing, sewing materials, and manicure products to support the members' individual businesses

loans.name: La Union En Progreso 1 Group

texts.en:
Hipolita is a member of the “La Union en Progreso 1” (the unit to progress). They are micro businesspeople in clothing sales, sales of natural products, shoes, teachers, food sales, etc. in the city of Hato Mayor, one of the most rural cities in the country whose economy depends on agriculture.

This associate of Esperanza is a mother of four children. She’s married and started her business with some of her savings. She is now in her fourth year and receiving her 8th loan. Each previous loan has been repaid satisfactorily and she has maD. good investments.

She is currently operating a “Decoration businees” she sews bedlinen and curtains, also she fabrics pillow cover, branchet, and complements for bedroom and bathroom. She is planning to use the new loan to buy linen, threads, embellishments, needles, etc.

She will use profits to reinvest in her business, to pay public utilities and to save some in order to help her children and improve her business.

Her favorite pastime is to do business and her primary challenge is caring for her children.

loans.use: to buy linen, threads, embellishments, needles, etc.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.es: Marcelina, de 60 años, vive en su casa que es propia al lado de su esposo José de 64 años y sus 3 jóvenes hijos; juntos se esfuerzan a diario para salir adelante. Lleva casi 4 años dedicada a la venta de golosinas, gaseosas y productos de primera necesidad en una pieza habilitada de su casa. Empieza su labor a las 7 de la mañana y puede quedarse atendiendo hasta las 9 de la noche, pues dice que mayores son las ganancias mientras más tiempo tenga abierto el negocio; algunas veces cuenta con el apoyo en la atención de sus hijos o de su pareja cuando ella debe salir. Esta muy satisfecha con el negocio pues le permite realizar sus labores del hogar sin problemas, además de ayudar a su esposo en los gastos del hogar. Como es una dama muy emprendedora para el futuro tiene planeado instalar una librería en una parte de su tienda, pues no hay ninguna por la zona donde vive y calcula que tendría mucho éxito. Es el séptimo crédito que tiene con MFP y promete pagar sus cuotas puntualmente, pues no quiere quedar mal con las personas que hicieron posible el dinero que le permitirá continuar adelante con su negocio. Marcelina tiene planeado invertir el crédito solicitado en la compra de alimentos que necesita para surtir bien su negocio, pues quiere ofrecer lo mejor a sus clientes.
texts.en: Marcelina is 60 years old she lives in her own home with her husband, José who is 64 years old and their 3 young children. They work hard each day to get ahead. For almost 4 years, Marcelina has sold candy, beverages and basic household goods in a room in her home. She begins working from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m. and says that most of her earnings are due to how long the business is open. Sometimes she has help from her children or her partner when she has to go out. Marcelina is very happy with the business since it allows her to do housework without problems and it helps her husband meet the household expenses. Since she is a very enterprising woman concerned about the future, she plans to have a bookshop in her store since there isn’t one in the area where she lives and believes that it will be successful. This is her seventh loan with MFP (Kiva’s field partner) and is committed to meet the payments on time since she doesn’t want to deceive the people who helped her get the money that will allow her to continue successfully with her business. Marcelina plans to use the loan to buy foodstuffs that she needs to stock her business since she wants to offer the best to her customers.

loans.use: To buy various products to stock her store.

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Group

texts.en:
For the creation of the committee, Ms. Idolvina contacted her neighbors and friends to form the committee. She lives in Ciudad del Este and she is into poultry. She is very eager to upgrade her business. She wants to increase her merchandise quantity, thus increasing her income.

The committee is names "Mujeres Trabajadoras" (Working Women), and it has 18 very active members who live in the same area. They each have different activities to earn a salary. The credit will help them buy the necessary sales merchandise for their businesses.

loans.use: The buying of chickens.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Berthalina

texts.es: Berthalina tiene 49 años por lo que es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos, Es una mujer muy responsable ya que tiene 6 hijos pero solamente 3 hijos están a su cargo y los mantiene ella ya que es madre soltera. Su actividad económica es una pulpería, por lo que más de 8 años que se dedica a este negocio a pesar de las dificultades que enfrento como es el poco apoyo que tenia por lo que no tenía el capital suficiente para invertir en todos los productos. Ahora solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de golosinas, café, jugos, pan, galletas y gaseosas.
texts.en:
Berthalina is 49 years old and this is the first time she has received financing. She is a very responsible woman who has six children, but only three of them are dependents. Berthalina takes care of them as a single mother. For more than eight years, she has managed a store despite the difficulties she has faced. Berthalina has little support and does not have sufficient capital to invest in all of her products.

Now she is requesting this loan to use as operating capital to buy candy, coffee, juices, bread, cookies, and sodas.

loans.use: Operating capital to buy candy, coffee, juices, bread, cookies, and sodas

loans.name: Lahidou Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Lahidou, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 32 ans, 5 enfants et vivent majoritairement dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Belenikoro, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce du bois de chauffe, du charbon de bois, des habillements et d’articles divers. Les femmes du groupe Lahidou sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire.                                                                                                                                
AMINATA T. compte acheter des chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe auprès des paysans  du village. Elle effectue ses ventes à la maison, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Lahidou group are all married and average 32 years of age and five children. Most of them live in extended traditional families in Belenikoro, a village in Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through bonds of kinship, neighborhood and friendship. They trade in firewood, charcoal, clothes, and various other products. They women of the Lahidou group are seeking their second group loan.

AMINATA T. intends to buy cartloads of firewood from farmers in the village. She sells at her home, for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women. She intends to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 25'000 (ca US$ 50) to be used to repay the loan and pay her contributions to social ceremonies, while the remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy firewood

loans.name: Berminda Del Carmen

texts.es:
Berminda tiene 46 años D. edad, es madre soltera, y tiene 1 hija. Vive en casa D. su padre junto a su familia en el distrito D. Chiclayo, exactamente en el distrito D. José Leonardo Ortiz.

Se dedica desD. hace ocho años a la comercialización D. verduras y D. tubérculos en un puesto D. venta ubicado en el mercado D. José Leonardo Ortiz, ella adquiere su mercadería en el mercado mayorista D. la ciudad D. Chiclayo y la ofrece todos los dias a sus clientes. Este negocio es una importante fuente D. ingresos que ayudan con los gastos familiares.

Su negocio goza D. una buena acogida, por ello Berminda desea ampliarlo con la compra D. más verduras para ofrecerlas a sus clientes. Por este motivo ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 1000 nuevos soles que le permitan lograr su objetivo.

Berminda es una mujer tranquila y que goza D. mucha estima en la zona donD. vive. Sus clientes prefieren su negocio porque ella siempre los recibe con un trato amable y una amplia sonrisa.
texts.en:
Berminda, 46, is a single mother of one daughter.  She lives in her father’s house with her family in Chiclayo District, precisely in José Leonardo Ortiz District.

For the last 8 years she’s been selling vegetables and tubers in a stand located in the José Leonardo Ortiz market.  She gets her merchandise in the city of Chiclayo’s wholesale market and she is open for business every day.  This business is an important source of income that she uses to help meet family expenses.

Her business is well received and she is very well liked in the area where she lives.  Her customers prefer her business because she always greets them with kind treatment and a wiD. smile.

loans.use: to buy vegetables.

loans.name: Hang's Group

texts.en:
Hang T. T. D. is 41 years old. She has 3 children in high school and secondary school. Being a farmer, she grows rice to support her family's diet.  In order to have more money to cover her expenses, she runs a business that focuses on construction delivery.  Her business has lasted for 10 years and brings a stable income that helps her to improve her living conditions. Participating in our credit program since 2007, she has received loans 7 times with increasing loan sizes. She has used them effectively in expanding her business. She requests 7,630,000 Vietnamese dong for this new loan cycle to buy a mini truck.

Phuoc T. N. P. is 33 years old with 2 children. She runs a tailoring shop. She needs a loan of 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong to buy clothes.

Huong T. N. is 35 years old with 2 children. She is raising 200 chickens for meat. She needs a loan of 7,194,000 Vietnamese dong to buy food for the chickens.

Oanh T. N. is 45 years old with 3 children. She is a wood carver and makes wood equipment. She needs a loan of 7,194,000 Vietnamese dong to buy some tools that will help her work more productively.

Linh  H. N. is 30 years old with 2 children. She is an accountant for a private company. She wants a loan of 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong to use for painting her house.

loans.use: to buy a mini truck

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn works hard to support four children. She is married and has a sari-sari (variety) store business in the Philippines. Jocelyn requested a PHP 3,500 loan through NWTF to buy a SOLAR LAMP.

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to have emergency light and save energy expense.

Jocelyn is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: To purchase a Solar Lamp.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more tailoring supplies and a new motorbike.

loans.name: Artykul's Group

texts.en:
Artykul is the leader of this group.  She is 53 and married to a driver. Together with her husband, she has raised four children. Three of the children are married and live separately with their families.  The youngest daughter, 18, just graduated from school and is going to enter the university. In order to earn money to meet the family needs, Artykul breeds livestock animals and then resells them at a higher price. In this way, she earns an additional 2,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase two more farm animals for breeding. In the near future, Artykul wants her daughter to enter a good university.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase farm animals
